reviewText: The problem with giving this film any credit at all for its merits, which lie in the clever script and the excellent performance of Philip Seymour Hoffman, is that there is no way of separating any single good aspect of the film from the greater project behind it, and that project is transparent Hollywood-Pentagon Propaganda.  This is not a finessing of a potentially controversial movie to smooth out the rougher edges and garner a broader audience.  This is not a crass commercialization of a complex and nuanced story to turn it into an easily digestible popcorn film.  This is nothing more or less than Hollywood operating in conjunction with the Marine Motion Picture Liaison Center to deliberately rewrite history and blatantly fabricate the history of U.S. covert activity in the Russo-Afghan War.  It is even admitted that there was an on-set CIA agent "advising" on the script.You don't need to be a diligent student of Deep Politics, the CIA, or the Military Industrial Complex to grasp what blatant PR this film is.  You just need simple common sense.  The moral landscape of the film is uncomplicated.  The CIA operatives are cynical, but unambiguously noble in their intentions.  Hanks is primarily motivated by his deep caring of the suffering in Pakistan or something, and that's how he garners the support of the head of the Defense Appropriations Committee(!)  The fact that the US admits to have armed Afghanistan to incite a war with Russia before Russia was even there is not mentioned (and don't even think of the continuing relations between the US Gov. and extremist radical factions throughout the 80's and 90's).  They grossly overstate the effectiveness of the Stinger.  A crucial pivot point of the plot occurs when the Stinger, once provided to Afghan troops, proves to be a Super-Secret Weapon that the Godless Commies (they are seen joking about cheating on their wives in planes) just can never handle.  This should be ludicrous on its face to anyone with basic sense.It is precisely the silliness of the core political content (which in an overtly political film, is the core content) that makes the film resort to gratuitously overplaying the irrelevant angle of Charlie Wilson's libido.  Possibly half the film consists of  Charlie Wilson ogling his numerous nubile Congressional aids, or recounting Wilson's past and present affairs with sexy lobbyists, sexy fundraisers, sexy staffers, belly dancers, etc.  This is just overwrought characterization that does not drive or even influence the narrative in any way.  It's just eye candy thrown in all over the script for tits and giggles. It's as if someone were to write a Hollywood script about the political career of Jimmy Carter and replace Mondale and Brzezinsky with porn stars who brief (and debrief) Carter in a hot tub.  (While Jimmy Carter in a hot tub is an unpleasant thought, it's not as if anyone is going to be wowed by the snippet of Tom Hanks' 50-year-old bare tuckus.)  The only contribution that any of this makes to the film is the way in which it suggests how Charlie Wilson may have been used to bag money for the CIA's clandestine operations; the CIA probably used his indulgences in drugs and women against him as blackmail material. This is plausible to anyone who has the most rudimentary understanding of how the CIA operates, but it isn't even hinted at in the movie; or if it is, you'd have to be viewing it critically enough to know that the plot is bunk just to get the hint.So this is essentially two pointless films disguised as one allegedly meaningful film.  There is one romantic comedy about our fun-loving playboy Charlie Wilson who lives it up...period.  He sings, he dances, he tells jokes, but nothing happens.  His antics have no bearing on the main plot, they lead to no dramatic personal conflict, he learns nothing, the character doesn't arc and that subplot goes nowhere.  On the other hand, you have another historical/political film that is so deeply deceptive in the domains of history or politics that it insults the intelligence of the viewer.  And even on it's own terms, the narrative is anticlimactic.  Nothing is at stake except how to get arms to the film's heroes, the Mujahadeen (aka Al Qaeda); but they solve the "problem" a third of the way into the film.  First they fund/arm them and then they fund/arm them more, and keep funding/arming them, and then the war stops, and they stop funding them. That's the narrative arc.The ending of the film may be the most pathetically disingenuous aspect of it.  It is there when the cynicism of the film is at its starkest and its most brazen.  Charlie wants the government to fund schools for the Afghans, but the supposedly cynical and hardened Defense Appropriations Committee will have none of it.  This is supposedly Charlie Wilson's transformative moment as he ponders on the political system's lack of compassion as the film ends.  But once you get past the violins and the dramatic close-ups, a moment's reflection reveals that it's a fraud.  There is no there there.  The integrity of the system was never at stake, and it was never subverted.  It was never even an issue.  Charlie Wilson's conscience was clean throughout and this revelation that they were going to "abandon" the Afghans did not retroactively tarnish anything he did.  The issue was Charlie Wilson supposedly manipulating the Defense Appropriations Committee to arm the Afghans to bomb the hell out of the Russians, and that's exactly what he/they did. Charlie Wilson lived it up as the Afghans, armed with their Super-Stinger Weapon blew the Commie Bastards into the Great Unknown.  When they refused to fund schools, the most charitable reading of his character possible would have him feeling disappointed.  Less charitable readings would have him feeling indifferent.  No sensible reading would leave him devastated or transformed because the decision had no larger implications about his role in the events or his greater worldview.  And that's the fraud.  The movie uses dramatic cinematography, music, and lighting to manipulate the viewer into thinking that his worldview was challenged somewhere in the film, and it leaves the naive viewer with the impression that he has received a dose of the cruel and cold realities of politics, and that he is a wiser person for having seen it.  In reality, of course, his worldview was not intended to be challenged , but deliberately and manipulatively reinforced.  The issue of corruption is treated as though dire and subversive, but in effect comes across as a dingy spot on the otherwise glorious armor borne by the Great White Knight of US Foreign Policy.  The intended effect of this film, in conjunction with others like it, is to produce a peculiar sort of outlook that imagines itself to be skeptical and hardened while in reality being the most naive form of government fetishism.  That's why there have to be moments of fake introspection and fake moral dilemmas, such as in Black Hawk Down, The Hurt Locker, and Munich.  After Vietnam, the American public cannot really accept raw, unadulterated jingoism in their patriotic movies, so they have to throw a bit of token skepticism, just enough to leave the audience feeling worldly and wise while in reality swallowing the same indoctrination as always.  The more I think about it, the more disgusted I get.  One star.

reviewText: Political films are some of the hardest in Hollywood to pull off smoothly.  Either the subject matter is too controversial, it paints someone in too positive/negative of a light, or it flat out messes with history to fit a dramatic tone.  "Charlie Wilson's War" suffered from none of these problems, yet still managed to underwhelm due to a completely unexpected source: it couldn't decided whether it wanted to be gripping, or a farce.Basically, this movie tells the story of U.S. Senator Charles Wilson, who (during the Soviet-Afghanistan conflict) was so inspired by the courage of the Afghan troops in fending off the Russians that he launched a covert "campaign" of sorts to get the Afghans the funding/weapons they needed to defeat the spread of Communism from the Soviets.  As history bears out, Wilson succeeds in this task and is regarded as a hero...at least for the time being.This entire film could have taken (and would have been much better off, in my opinion) a more serious tact to the political issues being dealt with, like the lack of funding to an Afghanistan "military" that was essentially fighting the Soviets for the United States, or the fact that Afghanistan went on to produce the terrorists that perpetuated 9/11 and we are now fighting.  This approach could have been a great sort of dramatic "treatise" on those issues and could have made people really think about them.Unfortunately, the film does not take that sort of tone, and instead focuses on the character of Charlie Wilson.  While obviously at the center of all the goings-on, this prolonged focus on Wilson's personality and private life only served to drag the film down.  Plus, all the characters (but essentially Tom Hanks' Wilson and his lady-friend played by Julia Roberts) seem way too over the top in their interactions with each other and the plot at hand.  I realize the intent of the filmmakers, which was to show what a maverick Charles Wilson really was, but to me that wasn't the most interesting part of the story.Thus, "Charlie Wilson's War" is a respectable film dealing with an interesting political event, yet views those happenings through a prism (the crazy Wilson) that isn't altogether engaging.  While the focus on the Afghan-Soviet conflict is refreshing (not just World War 2 or terrorism), it isn't played for the type of drama that could have occurred.  Involved political minds will find it interesting, while lesser scribes may drift off as the message gets lost in Hanks' over-the-top portrayal of Wilson.
summary: Could Have Been Epic, But Instead Was Just Interesting
